body_html:
@antifriz your interpretation of the examples in the window dataset documentation is incorrect.

The result of applying the window transformation is a nested dataset, which needs to be flattened before it can be evaluated. One such mechanism for flattening a dataset is flat_map.

For instance,

dataset = tf.data.Dataset.range(7).window(2).flat_map(lambda x: x.skip(1))

produces a dataset that skips all even elements of the original range.

The result of applying the window transformation is a nested dataset, which needs to be flattened before it can be evaluated. One such mechanism for flattening a dataset is flat_map.
For instance,

produces a dataset that skips all even elements of the original range.
body:
@antifriz your interpretation of the examples in the `window` dataset documentation is incorrect.

The result of applying the `window` transformation is a nested dataset, which needs to be flattened before it can be evaluated. One such mechanism for flattening a dataset is `flat_map`.

For instance,

```
dataset = tf.data.Dataset.range(7).window(2).flat_map(lambda x: x.skip(1))
```

produces a dataset that skips all even elements of the original range.
